Remotely Accesing a File Server with Tailscale

Last Updated
January 15, 2026

Set up a free and simple VPN tunnel to access and modify a remote file server in the most secure way possible, wile still being pretty lazy.

Background

The goal is to be able to securely access and manipulate the files on a local file server. I don't have this problem very often, but occasionally it would be nice to be able to make changes to the files from outside of my local network. My understanding of security best practices suggests that the best way to actually accomplish this is with a third party piece of hardware, in this case, an old laptop with a broken screen.

The ideal path to connect would be to remote into the third party machine that stays connected to the same network as the file serve. I can leave an open VPN connection running on this machine, and access it anytime I want, and then simply remote into the file server once I'm connected.

Required Software

  • Tailscale: A very simple VPN service, with great apps for MacOS, Windows, Linux, BSD, Android and iOS.

  • OpenSSH: The most popular tool for remote access.

  • Scp or Rsync (or both): A tool to remotely move files and directories.

  • Curl: required for installing Tailscale on Linux

  • Terminus is a great option (it is worth noting that Terminus also runs on desktop). Additionally, I have installed scp on the third party machine, so that I can easily move files onto or retrieve files from the file server if I need to. You might also need to install curl on some minimal installations of Linux as a prerequisite.

Install Instructions

Dependencies (SSH, SCP & Curl)

Ubuntu

sudo apt install openssh-server curl &&
sudo systemctl enable --now sshd

Arch

sudo pacman -S openssh scp curl && 
sudo systemctl enable --now sshd

Fedora

sudo dnf install openssh-server scp curl &&
sudo systemctl enable --now sshd

FreeBSD

sudo pkg install openssh scp curl ; 
sudo kidload fuse && 
sudo sysrc sshd_enable="YES" &&
sudo service sshd start

MacOS (Via Homebrew)

brew install openssh scp curl &&
brew install --cask macfuse

Tailscale

Linux

curl -fsSL https://tailscale.com/install.sh | sh

Android or iOS

Install the app from the Google Play or iOS App Store and follow the in app prompts. All you should have to do it login to your Tailscale account and accept whatever permissions it requests.

MacOS

brew install tailscale

Starting Tailscale

Desktop (Linux, MacOS, Powershell)

sudo tailscale up

After starting the Tailscale process, an authentication link will be printed to the terminal. Follow the URL, sign in to a Tailscale account, and you'll be all set.

To stop an active VPN tunnel, run:

sudo Tailscale down

A Note on Unattended Use

By default a Tailscale connection will stay open until a user closes the process andior the machine is restarted. Particularly when run with sudo on Linux, the VPN tunnel will stay up regardless of which user is logged in, even if no user is logged in. It may be necessary on a Windows installation to run Tailscale with an additional flag for the same behavior to take place:

tailscale up --unattended=true

However, the best place for specific use case information is Tailscale's documentation, particularly the page on unattended use.

Android or iOS

Tailscale is toggled on an off via the respective phone application. Much the same as on desktop, once the VPN tunnel is open, by default it will remain open indefinitely. However in this case, if the Tailscale application is not kept open in the background, the connection will be closed.

Access

In order to connect to a device remotely all that is required is an open Tailscale tunnel on each device. I typically accomplish this by leaving Tailscale open and running on my broken laptop, and only opening up the machine I want to access with, when I'm ready to access. The easiest way to access the remote machine is via SSH.

SSH Access

Visiting https://login.tailscale.com on any device that you are logged in on, will provide a rundown of all machines authenticated with a given Tailscale account. Here you can easily find IP addresses for remote connection, and copy them to the clipboard. Once you have the IP address, the SSH syntax is the same as it would be if you were remotely accessing a device on LAN. By default Tailscale uses port 22 for SSH. It is important to know the username for the device you are accessing via Tailscale's service. However, per standard SSH operation the username part of the equation is irrelevant if you use the same username across machines.

ssh USER@100.XXX.XX.XX # If username is different between the two machines
ssh 100.XXX.XX.XX # If username is the same

A Note on SysAdmining

If you end up using this remote access method to manipulate files a lot, I would highly recommend looking into tmux, a multiplexer that will allow you to easily run multiple sessions via one remote connection. I made a YouTube video a few years ago going over how to use Tmux.

Moving Files

I use scp to move files from my remote access machine, to my file server. This allows me to download any files I might need on the remote access machine, and transfer them across my LAN. If you do not have a dedicated remote access machine and still want to perform this operation, it would be worth taking a look at Taildrop, a file sharing protocol currently in Alpha that aims to enable this exactly.

scp /path/to/local/file USER@REMOTE:/path/to/remote/directory/ # Basic Syntax
scp -r /path/to/local/file USER@REMOTE:/path/to/remote/directory/ # Basic Syntax

Usage

Removing the Middle Man

It's worth mentioning that there isn't a need for a third party piece of hardware to set enable this process. Tailscale's VPN tunnel should be more than secure enough that you could open the VPN tunnel on the file server itself. However, I would argue that having a third party device is a sound investment in peace of mind. With this setup, even if my remote connection was compromised, no one is going to be able to gain access to the actual file server. The machine that I'm using to connect to my local network is worthless by design. This machine has one job, and it's to act as a middle-man in this relay. If you don't have old hardware lying around, don't feel the need to buy an extra laptop or Raspberry Pi just for this job, but if you have any kind of old hardware that isn't being utilized, this is a great use case for it.
